items.title: Key points to unpack US attacks on Venezuela
items.description: These are the key points to get up to speed with what we know about the US strikes on Venezuela and the current state of play after its president was ousted and removed from the country.

items.title: Why did Venezuelan rally go ahead in Sydney despite protest restrictions?
items.description: New laws restricting protests were recently passed in NSW, yet close to 300 people took to the streets of Sydney after the US attack on Venezuela.

items.title: Prison escapee attacks Victorian farm worker
items.description: A farm worker says he was threatened by a man who escaped from Langi Kal Kal prison near Ballarat.

items.title: Cause of woman's death in custody still 'undetermined' after autopsy
items.description: Police say the cause of a woman's death in a Northern Territory police watch house last month remains "undetermined" following a post-mortem examination conducted on Friday.

items.title: Samsung to double Gemini-equipped devices to 800M

featured_image.name: Exclusive: Samsung to double mobile devices powered by Google's Gemini to 800 mln units this year

items.description:
Samsung Electronics plans to double the number of its mobile devices equipped with Google's Gemini AI features to 800 million units this year, co-CEO TM Roh told Reuters in an exclusive interview, marking a major escalation in the global artificial intelligence race. The South Korean tech giant, which deployed Gemini-backed AI features to approximately 400 million smartphones and tablets by the end of 2025, aims to apply AI "to all products, all functions, and all services as quickly as possible," Roh said[1][2][3][4].

The aggressive expansion gives Google a significant advantage as the world's largest Android device manufacturer deepens its AI partnership. Samsung is striving to reclaim its market leadership from Apple, which Counterpoint Research projects will be the top smartphone maker for 2025—the first time since 2011[5][6][7][8]. Samsung's surveys show awareness of its Galaxy AI brand surged to 80% from roughly 30% within just one year, signaling growing consumer adoption[1][2][3].

items.title: Venezuela's acting president proposes US cooperation

featured_image.name: Venezuela Supreme Court names Delcy Rodriguez acting president ...

items.description:
Venezuelan acting President Delcy Rodriguez made a notable shift in tone on Sunday, extending an invitation to the United States for a "cooperation agenda" just one day after condemning Washington's military operation that captured President Nicolás Maduro.

Rodriguez, who was named acting president by Venezuela's Supreme Court on Saturday following Maduro's detention, called for a "balanced and respectful relationship" between the two nations in a statement posted on Telegram[1][2][3]. "We extend an invitation to the US government to work together on an agenda for cooperation that is aimed toward shared development," she wrote, emphasizing that such cooperation should occur "within the framework of international law."[4][5]

Addressing President Donald Trump directly, Rodriguez said Venezuelans "deserve peace and dialogue, not war," adding that "this has always been the principle championed by President Maduro."[6][7][8] The statement marked a dramatic departure from her televised address on Saturday, when she surrounded herself with military leaders and declared "there is only one president in this country, and his name is Nicolás Maduro," while condemning the US operation as "barbaric."[9][10][11]

items.title: Portland astronomer captures rare interstellar comet
items.description:
As professional observatories tracked an ancient visitor from beyond our solar system, a Portland amateur astronomer achieved what many scientists struggle to capture: a clear image showing the distinct separation between the comet's nucleus and its tail.

Patrick Finney photographed interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS in early January using a consumer smart telescope from his backyard, documenting the rare celestial object as it departs after a months-long journey through the solar system[1][2]. The comet, only the third interstellar object ever detected, made its closest approach to Earth on December 19, passing at a distance of 270 million kilometers[1][2][3]. It remained invisible to the naked eye throughout its visit.

items.title: States brace for 'worst' heatwave since Black Summer
items.description: Blisteringly high temperatures are expected throughout Victoria and in parts of South Australia and New South Wales.

items.title: Trump says military operation against Colombia 'sounds good'

featured_image.name: President Trump Holds News Conference After US Captures Venezuelan President Maduro

items.description:
U.S. President Donald Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One on Sunday that a military operation against Colombia "sounds good to me," hours after threatening the country's leader to "watch his ass" following the capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro[1][2][3][4].

The remarks, made as Trump returned from Florida, represent an escalation of tensions with Colombian President Gustavo Petro and raised alarm across Latin America that Washington's military intervention in the region may expand beyond Venezuela. Secretary of State Marco Rubio separately suggested Cuba could be the next target, describing the Cuban government as "a huge problem" and saying they are "in a lot of trouble"[5][6][7].

items.title: Trump gambles on MAGA base backing his new imperialism
items.description: Donald Trump has long defied political gravity but whether his followers in Congress and the MAGA movement will follow him into a new colonialism is a big gamble.

items.title: Measles alert as Adelaide and Sydney airports among possible exposure sites
items.description: SA and NSW health authorities have issued alerts about a potential measles exposure risk, after a person with the disease recently caught a flight from Adelaide to Sydney.

items.title: AI safety experts warn systems outpace safeguards

featured_image.name: Leading AI companies' safety practices are falling short, new report says

items.description:
A chorus of AI safety experts and industry leaders is warning that the world may lack the time and infrastructure to manage the rapidly escalating risks posed by artificial intelligence, as new autonomous systems outpace existing safeguards.

David Dalrymple, an AI safety expert at the UK government's Advanced Research and Invention Agency, told The Guardian this week that AI development is moving "really fast" and that it cannot be assumed these "systems are reliable"[1]. His warning echoes concerns from OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, who stated in early January that AI is becoming increasingly "dangerous" not because it is inherently malicious, but because its capabilities are advancing faster than the systems designed to control them[2][3].

items.title: Venezuelan oil exports frozen after US captures Maduro

featured_image.name: Oil prices likely to move higher on Venezuelan turmoil, ample supply ...

items.description: In an operation President Donald Trump described as a display of overwhelming military power, US forces captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife early Saturday morning in Caracas, marking one of the most dramatic military interventions in recent American history[1][2]. The raid, dubbed Operation Absolute Resolve, has effectively paralyzed Venezuela's oil exports while raising questions about the lengthy timeline to revitalize the country's energy infrastructure.

items.title: Oil prices dip modestly after US captures Venezuelan leader

featured_image.name: Oil prices likely to move higher on Venezuelan turmoil, ample supply to cap gains

items.description:
Oil prices edged lower on Sunday despite the weekend capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro by US forces, as analysts said ample global supply would cushion any disruption from the oil-producing nation. Brent crude fell 22 cents to $60.53 per barrel, while US crude dropped 31 cents to $57.01[1].

The modest market reaction followed President Donald Trump's announcement Saturday that the United States would control Venezuela until an orderly transition could be arranged, after executing what he called a "large-scale strike" on the capital Caracas in the early hours of January 3[2][3]. Trump emphasized that securing US investments in Venezuela's oil sector was a primary goal, stating American oil companies were prepared to invest billions of dollars to restore production[1].

items.title: Danish PM tells Trump to stop threatening Greenland annexation

featured_image.name: Greenland, Denmark affirm alliance amid Trump's interest in ...

items.description:
Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen issued a forceful rebuke to President Donald Trump on Sunday, demanding that the United States cease threats to annex Greenland following renewed American interest in the Danish territory in the wake of the U.S. military operation in Venezuela.

"It makes absolutely no sense to talk about the need for the United States to take over Greenland," Frederiksen said in a statement Sunday[1][2][3][4]. "The U.S. has no right to annex any of the three nations in the Danish kingdom."

The sharp exchange between NATO allies came after Trump told The Atlantic in an interview published Sunday that "we do need Greenland, absolutely. We need it for defense"[1][5][4]. His comments followed a major U.S. military operation early Saturday that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas[4][6][7].

items.title: Live: Stokes removes Weatherald after solid opening partnership
items.description: Jake Weatherald fails to capitalise on two dropped chances as Ben Stokes strikes after the first drinks break in the final session. Follow live.

items.title: Live: Choppy trade for oil prices as analysts say Venezuela risks 'ambiguous'
items.description: Australian shares are trading fairly flat on Monday, while oil prices rebound following the US strike on Venezuela that sparked concerns about oversupply. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

items.title: Rubio softens Trump claim US will 'run' Venezuela

featured_image.name: U.S. Oil 'Quarantine' of Venezuela Will Remain, and Troops ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Saturday that the United States would temporarily "run" Venezuela following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro in a dramatic overnight military operation, but Secretary of State Marco Rubio appeared to soften that stance on Sunday, suggesting Washington would use oil leverage rather than govern the country directly[1][2].

Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, were seized from their home in Caracas early Saturday during a raid by U.S. special forces and transported to New York, where they are being held at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn ahead of a Monday court appearance on narco-terrorism charges[3][4]. Trump told reporters the U.S. would "run the country until such time as we can do a safe, proper and judicious transition"[3][1].

Yet on Sunday morning talk shows, Rubio walked back those assertions. "People keep fixating on that," he told NBC's "Meet the Press," clarifying that the U.S. would continue enforcing an oil quarantine to press for policy changes rather than governing Venezuela day-to-day[1][2]. "We expect to see changes in Venezuela," Rubio said, adding the U.S. would use control of sanctioned oil as "tremendous leverage"[2].

items.title: Trump says U.S. 'absolutely needs' Greenland

featured_image.name: Trump says he's dropping push for National Guard in Portland ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Sunday reaffirmed his intention to acquire Greenland, telling The Atlantic magazine "we absolutely need Greenland" for national security, describing the island as surrounded by Russian and Chinese ships[1][2]. The renewed pressure on Denmark came just hours after a controversial U.S. military operation that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, sparking fears among European allies that Trump's expansionist rhetoric could extend to the Arctic territory.

The timing amplified diplomatic tensions when Katie Miller, wife of White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller, posted an image of Greenland draped in the American flag on social media late Saturday with a single word: "SOON"[3][4][5]. Denmark's ambassador to the United States, Jesper Moeller Soerensen, responded swiftly, declaring his country expects "full respect for the territorial integrity of the Kingdom of Denmark"[3][4].

items.title: Live: Trump doubles down on oil plans for Venezuela, floats US operation in Colombia
items.description: It comes as US Secretary of State Marco Rubio says discussions of Venezuela holding elections following Nicolás Maduro's ouster are "premature", with Washington focused on ensuring Caracas now carries out policy changes.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video

items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
